states: all alike, relatively massive, sessile and coalescing in two rows on the spikelike fertile component of the leaf <\i{}Ophioglossum\i0{}>

in paired sporocarps borne on the submerged ventral lobes of the first leaves of the branches, each sporocarp covered by a flange of the upper lobe, containing one sorus on a cylindrical receptacle and the sori of each pair either both containing megasporangia, or both with one microsporangium and one megasporangium (the former with 64 tiny microspores, the latter with a single large megaspore) <\i{}Azolla\i0{}>

in tiny, 4-compartmented, hairy, pill-like sporocarps at the bases of the subulate green leaves, the compartments each containing one sorus which splits longitudinally at maturity to release the sporangia in a mass of mucilage (the one-spored megasporangia borne below the many-spored microsporangia in the same sorus) <\i{}Pilularia\i0{}>
tiny and delicate, stalked, all alike, borne in aggregates <usually grouped in sori: typical of most ferns>

<local in Ireland and Western Britain from Cornwall to N. Ebudes, also in E. Sussex>
<local in Ireland and western Britain, with a similar distribution there but commoner than \i{}H. tunbrigense\i0{}, and north to Shetland, but not in E. Sussex>
<mainland-European, commonly cultivated, and naturalized in southern and central Scotland, Westmoreland, Salop, and Northern Ireland>
<native to eastern North America and eastern Asia, naturalized in CW and SW Scotland, W Wales, NW and S England, and Jersey>
<scattered around coasts of the British Isles, not in eastern Ireland, eastern Scotland or eastern England except Cheviot (Stace, 1997)>
<local in Guernsey and the Scillies>
<frequent throughout most of the British Isles>
<with a similar distribution to \i{}Phegopteris connectilis\i0{} (q.v.) in western and northern Britain, but commoner, and also frequent in SW and SE England>
<recorded throughout the British Isles and common in parts of western Britain and western Ireland, but absent from large areas of eastern Britain>
<quite common in northern and western Britain, scattered in Ireland, but absent from most of southern, central and eastern England>
<common throughout the British Isles, except for its scattered distribution in northern Scotland>
<native to Australasia, naturalized in S Kerry, Guernsey and the Isles of Scilly>
<throughout the British Isles, formerly much commoner, now frequent only in central western Ireland, central southern England and parts of Wales>
<scattered in Ireland, western Britain north to central Scotland, in southern England to east Kent, also Guernsey>
<with a similar distribution to \i{}P. vulgare\i0{} (q.v.), but commoner in the South rare in the North, present in Channel Isles and absent from Orkney and Shetland>
<common throughout the British Isles>
<frequent in Britain and Ireland, common in N and W Britain, less common than \i{}P. setiferum\i0{} in SW England and S Wales>
<local in northern England, central and northern Scotland, Caerns and Dumfries, and in western Ireland, naturalized in Northants>
<on a shady laneside bank in Surrey>
<Channel Islands, S and W Britain and Ireland, rarer in the NE and absent from northern and eastern Scotland>
<abundant throughout the British Isles>
<central and northern Scotland, south to central Perthshire>
<native to southern Europe, naturalized in central and southern England>
<scattered in Britain and Ireland, north to central Scotland, but decreasing and now frequent only in East Anglia>

<now very local in western and central England, Wales, SW Scotland, and (mainly) SW Ireland. Formerly commoner, as evidenced by gametophytes surviving in parts of N and SW England and N Wales where sporophytes no longer develop>
<very local, in Caerns and central Scotland, decreasing>
<very local in Caerns, Cumberland, Dumfries and Angus, formerly more widespread>
<regenerates in gardens in S. Kerry and W. Cornwall>

Clapham, Tutin and Warburg described \i{}A. fontanum\i0{} as similar to \i{}A. obovatum\i0{}, but smaller and slenderer, but Sowerby's illustration depicts a plant with once-pinnate leaves>

<an apogamous hybrid derivative of \i{}D. affinis\i0{} x \i{}D. expansa\i0{}>
<the leaves glandular on both sides>

<It may be preferable to treat \i{}Phymatosorus\i0{} and \i{}Phymatodes\i0{} as synonyms of \i{}Microsorum\i0{} (cf. Bostock and Stokes, 1998). Furthermore, the current name of the British representative appears to be \i{}Microsorum pustulatum\i0{} (G.Forst.) Copel.>

<the rather variable \i{}P. aquilinum\i0{} sensu lato occurs world-wide, and has a long history of sub-division into inadequately defined species, sub-species and varieties. In his 1997 treatment, Stace assumed that only two taxonomic groupings, treated as sub-species complexes, are usefully recognisable in the N. Hemisphere. Subspecies \i{}aquilinum\i0{} represents the commonest components of the \i{}Pteridium\i0{} complex in Britain (see \i{}P. aquilinum\i0{} subsp. \i{}latiusculum\i0{})>

<the rather variable \i{}P. aquilinum\i0{} sensu lato occurs world-wide, and has a long history of sub-division into inadequately defined species, sub-species and varieties.
